Peter Drucker gave an interview to Bruce Rosenstein on April 11, 2005.  

Bruce wrote about the interview in his book.  

The book is titled *Living in More Than One World: How Peter Drucker’s Wisdom Can Inspire and Transform Your Life*.  

It was published by Berrett-Koehler in San Francisco, CA, in 2009.  

*Race to Nowhere: The Dark Side of America’s Achievement Culture* is a documentary.  

It was directed by Vicki Abeles in 2011.  

This documentary is part of a movement in schools.  

They aim to fight Nonessentialism in school.  

They work to reduce unnecessary homework and stress on children.  

You can visit their website at www.racetonowhere.com.  

Many citations exist for similar statements.  

Emile Gauvreau is one example.  

He said, “I was part of that strange race of people aptly described as spending their lives doing things they detest, to make money they don’t want, to buy things they don’t need, to impress people they don’t like.”  

This quote is from Jay Friedenberg's book, *Artificial Psychology: The Quest for What It Means to Be Human*.  

Mary Oliver wrote “The Summer Day.”  

This poem appears in *New and Selected Poems*, volume 1.  

The book was published by Beacon Press in Boston in 1992.  

M. E. P. Seligman wrote about “Learned Helplessness.”  

This article appeared in the *Annual Review of Medicine* in 1972.  

William James wrote letters that were edited by Henry James.  

These letters were published by Atlantic Monthly Press in Boston in 1920.  

John Carlin wrote, “If the World’s Greatest Chef Cooked for a Living, He’d Starve.”  

This article was published in the *Guardian* on December 11, 2006.  

Joseph Moses Juran wrote the *Quality-Control Handbook*.  

This book was published in New York by McGraw-Hill.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** The documentary "Race to Nowhere" addresses the negative impacts of America's achievement culture by advocating for reduced homework and stress in schools.
